name: California Roll
description: Filled with creamy avocado, sweet crabmeat, and crunchy cucumber, California Roll is by far the most popular style of rolled sushi in the US. Learn how to make delicious, perfect rolls every time at home following my step-by-step guide and photos.
recipeIngredient: 2¬º cups uncooked Japanese short-grain white rice
1 piece kombu (dried kelp) ((5 g; 2 x 2 inches, 5 x 5 cm per piece; optional, for a nice aroma!))
‚Öì cup seasoned rice vinegar (sushi vinegar) ((or make the homemade recipe below))
toppings of your choice ((try ikura (salmon roe) or yuzu-flavored tobiko (flying fish roe); optional))

recipeInstructions.text: Gather all the ingredients. Each California Roll requires ¬æ cup (110 g) of sushi rice, so you‚Äòll need about 6 cups (880 g) of sushi rice to make 8 rolls.
recipeInstructions.name: Gather all the ingredients. Each California Roll requires ¬æ cup (110 g) of sushi rice, so you‚Äòll need about 6 cups (880 g) of sushi rice to make 8 rolls.

itemListElement.text: Wash and Rinse: Put 2¬º cups uncooked Japanese short-grain white rice in a large bowl. Add enough cold tap water to wet the rice, then drain. Use your fingers to gently agitate and ‚Äúwash‚Äú the wet rice grains in a circular motion for 10‚Äì15 seconds. Using very little water allows the grains to rub against each other. Next, add water to the bowl to rinse, then immediately pour off the cloudy water. Repeat this wash and rinse step two more times or until the water is almost clear. Then, drain the rice well in a fine-mesh sieve and shake off any excess water.
itemListElement.name: Wash and Rinse: Put 2¬º cups uncooked Japanese short-grain white rice in a large bowl. Add enough cold tap water to wet the rice, then drain. Use your fingers to gently agitate and ‚Äúwash‚Äú the wet rice grains in a circular motion for 10‚Äì15 seconds. Using very little water allows the grains to rub against each other. Next, add water to the bowl to rinse, then immediately pour off the cloudy water. Repeat this wash and rinse step two more times or until the water is almost clear. Then, drain the rice well in a fine-mesh sieve and shake off any excess water.

itemListElement.text: Soak and Cook: Transfer the well-drained rice to the inner pot of a rice cooker. Add 2¬º cups water to the pot. Level the rice, then place 1 piece kombu (dried kelp) on top. Let the rice soak in the water for¬†20‚Äì30 minutes.¬†Then, start cooking. If you don‚Äòt have a rice cooker, cook the rice in a¬†pot on the stove,¬†Instant Pot, or¬†donabe¬†with the measured water I specified in this recipe.
itemListElement.name: Soak and Cook: Transfer the well-drained rice to the inner pot of a rice cooker. Add 2¬º cups water to the pot. Level the rice, then place 1 piece kombu (dried kelp) on top. Let the rice soak in the water for¬†20‚Äì30 minutes.¬†Then, start cooking. If you don‚Äòt have a rice cooker, cook the rice in a¬†pot on the stove,¬†Instant Pot, or¬†donabe¬†with the measured water I specified in this recipe.

itemListElement.text: Homemade Sushi Vinegar (optional): Combine ‚Öì cup rice vinegar (unseasoned), 3 Tbsp sugar, and 1¬Ω tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt in a small saucepan. Bring it to almost simmering over medium-high heat. Whisk until the sugar completely dissolves. You can also put the ingredients in a microwave-safe bowl and heat in the microwave for 1 minute, or until the sugar dissolves. Set aside to let it cool.
itemListElement.name: Homemade Sushi Vinegar (optional): Combine ‚Öì cup rice vinegar (unseasoned), 3 Tbsp sugar, and 1¬Ω tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt in a small saucepan. Bring it to almost simmering over medium-high heat. Whisk until the sugar completely dissolves. You can also put the ingredients in a microwave-safe bowl and heat in the microwave for 1 minute, or until the sugar dissolves. Set aside to let it cool.

itemListElement.text: Season the Rice: When the rice is cooked, discard the used kombu (or repurpose it to make¬†simmered kombu).
itemListElement.name: Season the Rice: When the rice is cooked, discard the used kombu (or repurpose it to make¬†simmered kombu).

itemListElement.text: If using a sushi oke (hangiri), first moisten it with running water, drain well, and dry with a clean towel. Next, transfer the hot cooked rice to the sushi oke or a large salad bowl or baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Then, spread out the rice evenly so it will cool faster. Tip: A wooden tub helps absorb excess moisture while a ceramic bowl can‚Äòt.
itemListElement.name: If using a sushi oke (hangiri), first moisten it with running water, drain well, and dry with a clean towel. Next, transfer the hot cooked rice to the sushi oke or a large salad bowl or baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Then, spread out the rice evenly so it will cool faster. Tip: A wooden tub helps absorb excess moisture while a ceramic bowl can‚Äòt.

itemListElement.text: Immediately pour ‚Öì cup seasoned rice vinegar (sushi vinegar) or the cooled homemade sushi vinegar over the hot rice.
itemListElement.name: Immediately pour ‚Öì cup seasoned rice vinegar (sushi vinegar) or the cooled homemade sushi vinegar over the hot rice.

itemListElement.text: With a rice paddle, gently ‚Äúslice‚Äù the hot rice at a 45-degree angle to incorporate the sushi vinegar and separate the rice chunks. Do not stir or mash the rice because that may break the grains and make the rice mushy. While slicing, vigorously fan the rice with a paddle fan or other fan to remove the excess moisture and make the rice shine.
itemListElement.name: With a rice paddle, gently ‚Äúslice‚Äù the hot rice at a 45-degree angle to incorporate the sushi vinegar and separate the rice chunks. Do not stir or mash the rice because that may break the grains and make the rice mushy. While slicing, vigorously fan the rice with a paddle fan or other fan to remove the excess moisture and make the rice shine.

itemListElement.text: Cover the prepared sushi rice with a damp cloth at all times to prevent it from drying.
itemListElement.name: Cover the prepared sushi rice with a damp cloth at all times to prevent it from drying.

itemListElement.text: Crabmeat: Remove 5 oz real or imitation crabmeat from the packaging. Cut it into smaller pieces, about 1 inch (2.5 cm) wide.
itemListElement.name: Crabmeat: Remove 5 oz real or imitation crabmeat from the packaging. Cut it into smaller pieces, about 1 inch (2.5 cm) wide.

itemListElement.text: Separate and shred the crabmeat with your fingers and place in a bowl. Add 1 Tbsp Japanese Kewpie mayonnaise and mix it all together.
itemListElement.name: Separate and shred the crabmeat with your fingers and place in a bowl. Add 1 Tbsp Japanese Kewpie mayonnaise and mix it all together.

itemListElement.text: Cucumber: Cut 2 Japanese or Persian cucumbers into quarters lengthwise.
itemListElement.name: Cucumber: Cut 2 Japanese or Persian cucumbers into quarters lengthwise.

itemListElement.text: Remove and discard the seeds. Then, cut the cucumber lengthwise into thin, long strips.
itemListElement.name: Remove and discard the seeds. Then, cut the cucumber lengthwise into thin, long strips.

itemListElement.text: Avocado: Cut 1 avocado (large) in half lengthwise around the seed. To do this, insert the knife through the skin and flesh until it meets the pit. Holding the knife in place, rotate the avocado with your other hand so the knife slices all the way around the pit. Next, twist the two halves until they separate.
itemListElement.name: Avocado: Cut 1 avocado (large) in half lengthwise around the seed. To do this, insert the knife through the skin and flesh until it meets the pit. Holding the knife in place, rotate the avocado with your other hand so the knife slices all the way around the pit. Next, twist the two halves until they separate.

itemListElement.text: To remove the pit, set the avocado half on the cutting board or hold it in your non-dominant hand with a folded kitchen towel for safety. Gently hack into the pit with the heel of the knife to embed its edge. Then, twist the knife and pit in a counter direction to the avocado. The pit will come out smoothly. To make thin slices, first cut the avocado halves in half again lengthwise (leave the skin on, for now).¬†
itemListElement.name: To remove the pit, set the avocado half on the cutting board or hold it in your non-dominant hand with a folded kitchen towel for safety. Gently hack into the pit with the heel of the knife to embed its edge. Then, twist the knife and pit in a counter direction to the avocado. The pit will come out smoothly. To make thin slices, first cut the avocado halves in half again lengthwise (leave the skin on, for now).¬†

itemListElement.text: Then, carefully cut them lengthwise into thin, ¬º-inch (6-mm) slices, again leaving the skin on. Squeeze the juice of ¬Ω lemon over the cut avocados to prevent them from turning brown.
itemListElement.name: Then, carefully cut them lengthwise into thin, ¬º-inch (6-mm) slices, again leaving the skin on. Squeeze the juice of ¬Ω lemon over the cut avocados to prevent them from turning brown.

itemListElement.text: Nori: Cut 4 sheets nori (dried laver seaweed) in half crosswise to make 8 half sheets.
itemListElement.name: Nori: Cut 4 sheets nori (dried laver seaweed) in half crosswise to make 8 half sheets.

itemListElement.text: Cover the front and back surfaces of the bamboo sushi mat with plastic wrap.
itemListElement.name: Cover the front and back surfaces of the bamboo sushi mat with plastic wrap.

itemListElement.text: Keep the sides uncovered so no air gets trapped.
itemListElement.name: Keep the sides uncovered so no air gets trapped.

itemListElement.text: Dip a ¬æ-cup measuring cup into a bowl of water to wet it and fill the cup with sushi rice.
itemListElement.name: Dip a ¬æ-cup measuring cup into a bowl of water to wet it and fill the cup with sushi rice.

itemListElement.text: Lay a nori half sheet, shiny side down, on the bamboo sushi mat. Wet your fingers in the water bowl and evenly spread ¬æ cup (110 g) sushi rice across the nori. Apply very gentle pressure so you don‚Äòt mash the rice grains. Alternatively, you can use a plastic rice paddle to keep your hands clean.
itemListElement.name: Lay a nori half sheet, shiny side down, on the bamboo sushi mat. Wet your fingers in the water bowl and evenly spread ¬æ cup (110 g) sushi rice across the nori. Apply very gentle pressure so you don‚Äòt mash the rice grains. Alternatively, you can use a plastic rice paddle to keep your hands clean.

itemListElement.text: Sprinkle the rice with about ¬Ω Tbsp toasted white sesame seeds.
itemListElement.name: Sprinkle the rice with about ¬Ω Tbsp toasted white sesame seeds.

itemListElement.text: Flip over the nori sheet so that the sushi rice is now facing down on the bamboo mat. Align the nori about 1 inch (2.5 cm) away from the bottom edge of the mat. Next, line up a portion of the crabmeat, avocado (skins removed), and cucumber across the width of the nori about ¬Ω inch (1.3 cm) away from the nori‚Äòs bottom edge.¬†Don‚Äòt add too much filling, or else it‚Äòll be extremely difficult to seal the roll.
itemListElement.name: Flip over the nori sheet so that the sushi rice is now facing down on the bamboo mat. Align the nori about 1 inch (2.5 cm) away from the bottom edge of the mat. Next, line up a portion of the crabmeat, avocado (skins removed), and cucumber across the width of the nori about ¬Ω inch (1.3 cm) away from the nori‚Äòs bottom edge.¬†Don‚Äòt add too much filling, or else it‚Äòll be extremely difficult to seal the roll.

itemListElement.text: To roll the sushi, grab the bottom edge of the mat with your index fingers and thumbs while holding the filling in place with your other fingers.
itemListElement.name: To roll the sushi, grab the bottom edge of the mat with your index fingers and thumbs while holding the filling in place with your other fingers.

itemListElement.text: Roll the sushi mat over the filling until the rice at the bottom edge meets the nori near the top edge. Then, flip back the mat‚Äòs bottom edge toward you.
itemListElement.name: Roll the sushi mat over the filling until the rice at the bottom edge meets the nori near the top edge. Then, flip back the mat‚Äòs bottom edge toward you.

itemListElement.text: Firmly squeeze the roll through the mat with one hand while you use your other hand to pull the top of the bamboo mat away from you. This helps form the roll into a tight cylinder.
itemListElement.name: Firmly squeeze the roll through the mat with one hand while you use your other hand to pull the top of the bamboo mat away from you. This helps form the roll into a tight cylinder.

itemListElement.text: Next, use one hand to lift and pull the bottom edge of the bamboo mat slightly as you use your other hand to roll the sushi forward through the bamboo mat. Keep gentle pressure on the mat as you roll.
itemListElement.name: Next, use one hand to lift and pull the bottom edge of the bamboo mat slightly as you use your other hand to roll the sushi forward through the bamboo mat. Keep gentle pressure on the mat as you roll.

itemListElement.text: To shape the roll, press on the top with your index fingers while squeezing the sides with your thumbs and other fingers. Your sushi roll is now done.Transfer the roll to a tray or plate and cover with a damp cloth at all times to prevent it from drying. Continue making the remaining rolls.
itemListElement.name: To shape the roll, press on the top with your index fingers while squeezing the sides with your thumbs and other fingers. Your sushi roll is now done.Transfer the roll to a tray or plate and cover with a damp cloth at all times to prevent it from drying. Continue making the remaining rolls.

itemListElement.text: With a very sharp knife, cut each roll in half crosswise. Then, cut each half into 4 pieces. Clean the knife with a damp cloth after every few cuts.
itemListElement.name: With a very sharp knife, cut each roll in half crosswise. Then, cut each half into 4 pieces. Clean the knife with a damp cloth after every few cuts.

itemListElement.text: Place the bamboo sushi mat over the cut roll and re-shape it one last time. Remove the mat and add the optional toppings of your choice, like ikura (salmon roe) or yuzu-flavored tobiko (flying fish roe).
itemListElement.name: Place the bamboo sushi mat over the cut roll and re-shape it one last time. Remove the mat and add the optional toppings of your choice, like ikura (salmon roe) or yuzu-flavored tobiko (flying fish roe).

itemListElement.text: Serve the California Rolls with a small dish of soy sauce and wasabi for dipping and pickled sushi ginger (optional) on the side. Enjoy!
itemListElement.name: Serve the California Rolls with a small dish of soy sauce and wasabi for dipping and pickled sushi ginger (optional) on the side. Enjoy!

itemListElement.text: It‚Äòs best to enjoy sushi rolls the same day you make them. Rice gets hard and dry in the refrigerator. If you really want to refrigerate them, my recommendation is to cover them with plastic and a thick kitchen towel, so the rice will stay cool and safe but not become cold.
itemListElement.name: It‚Äòs best to enjoy sushi rolls the same day you make them. Rice gets hard and dry in the refrigerator. If you really want to refrigerate them, my recommendation is to cover them with plastic and a thick kitchen towel, so the rice will stay cool and safe but not become cold.

review.reviewBody: It's not a quick and easy meal but the result is beyond amazing. My husband said that the rolls tasted better than 90% of restaurant rolls he tried, and my daughter said, "Mom, just stay in the kitchen" lol. My biggest discovery was that sushi is all about sushi rice. I'll have to convince my family to buy the fancy rice maker:)

Thank you very much for this website! I love Japanese food. Now thanks to you I learn how to cook it myself. üòä

I always struggled with sushi rice before. Until I found your page. 
This time I have followed each step precisely and got the perfect rice! I'm so happy! It was very easy to roll it. 
Thank you!

I made the mistake of placing too much rice onto the nori sheet. Consequently, it made it a challenge to roll into manageable bite-size pieces. After adjusting the rice portions according to the recipe it came out nicely. Nami wasn't kidding that practice makes perfect, especially when it comes to making sushi. This recipe is a keeper since everybody loved it! I can't wait to see what other variety of sushi the JOC team comes out with in addition to what they have now. Dragon rolls...you're next :)

Hello Namiko Chen ...

I was an international executive marketing manager at Sumitomo Electric for some 20 years, traveled extensively to Japan and ate Japanese food even more extensively (my belly still bulges). Coming back from Hokkaido during a trip, I must admit to having had 12 shrimp tempura one time for appetizer. I could never get enough!

Over time, that fact turned into rumor, and my reputation became (at last count) when I retired that I ate 48 tempura. We had so much fun with that, that I said nothing to dispel or decline the rumor.

Anyway, I am now 72 and am again intrigued with Japanese food, but this time I want to learn to make it myself. I am so grateful to have found your website. It is very professional, very beautiful with photography (doing Japanese presentation great justice) and I hope to acquire some of the skills to again enjoy Japanese cuisine.

Thank you for all your exquisite and hard work, excellent instructions and historical information. I will be a loyal fan.

Christoph
This is so fun and easy to make. thanks for sharing
